coredata.dc:title: The effect of temperature on the electrode properties of the directly prepared Ti3Ni2 alloy
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright © 2001 International Association for Hydrogen Energy. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
coredata.prism:publisher: International Association for Hydrogen Energy. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
coredata.dc:creator: Xu, Yan-hui
Chen, Chang-pin
Wang, Qi-dong
Chen, Li-xin
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The electrochemical properties of a new hydrogen storage alloy Ti3Ni2 have been studied in detail. The results show that the discharge capacity of Ti3Ni2 alloy reaches 384.4 mA h/g (corresponding to Ti3Ni2H3.7) at 353 K and 145.5 mA h/g (corresponding to Ti3Ni2H1.47) at 278 K. At the higher temperature (353 K), two plateaus appear on the discharge curve, and at the lower temperature (278 K) only one plateau. The kinetic property of Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode is poor. The following properties, namely the retention of charge, the activation of alloy, the kinetic property of Ti3Ni2 alloy (including the exchange current, the diffusion coefficient of hydrogen and high-rate dischargeability) can all be improved by increasing the temperature. It can be seen from X-ray diffraction analysis that two phases exist in alloy: namely the cubic Ti2NiH phase with Fe3W3C structure and the cubic TiNiH phase for the alloy cycled in alkaline solution, and the cubic Ti2NiH0.5 phase with Fe3W3C structure and the cubic TiNiH phase for the alloy hydrogenated with gaseous hydrogen.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Hydrogen storage alloy
Titanium nickel alloy
Electrode alloy
Electrochemistry

head.ce:title: The effect of temperature on the electrode properties of the directly prepared Ti3Ni2 alloy

ce:affiliation.ce:label: a
ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, People's Republic of China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The electrochemical properties of a new hydrogen storage alloy Ti3Ni2 have been studied in detail. The results show that the discharge capacity of Ti3Ni2 alloy reaches 384.4 mA h/g (corresponding to Ti3Ni2H3.7) at 353 K and 145.5 mA h/g (corresponding to Ti3Ni2H1.47) at 278 K. At the higher temperature (353 K), two plateaus appear on the discharge curve, and at the lower temperature (278 K) only one plateau. The kinetic property of Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode is poor. The following properties, namely the retention of charge, the activation of alloy, the kinetic property of Ti3Ni2 alloy (including the exchange current, the diffusion coefficient of hydrogen and high-rate dischargeability) can all be improved by increasing the temperature. It can be seen from X-ray diffraction analysis that two phases exist in alloy: namely the cubic Ti2NiH phase with Fe3W3C structure and the cubic TiNiH phase for the alloy cycled in alkaline solution, and the cubic Ti2NiH0.5 phase with Fe3W3C structure and the cubic TiNiH phase for the alloy hydrogenated with gaseous hydrogen.

ce:section.ce:para: Presently, Ni–MH battery is the most accessible application of hydrogen storage alloys (HSA). The HSA, including AB5-type family which has a hexagonal or orthorhombic structure with the CaCu5-type lattice [1,2], AB type with the CsCl-type structure (for example TiFe) [3,4], AB2 type which has two structures, namely the cubic C15 and hexagonal C14 [5,6], Mg-based alloys [7]. V-based alloys [8,9], AB3 type (for example LaNi3 and CaNi3) [10] AB13 type [11] etc., have wide applications, such as heat-pump, secondary battery, isotopic separation, etc. Now, many methods have been used to improve properties of the above HSA for different application fields: surface treatment, non-stoichiometry alloys, multiphase alloys, etc. The elements Cr,Co,Al,Nb,Pd, etc., are often used by researchers to improve the properties of all the above-mentioned alloys.

Now the development and research of the clean energy electric vehicle is fast because of the environment pollution in cities [12,13]. The key to EV R&D is the battery system which could operate well in the temperature range −30∼60°, Ni–MH battery is one of the promising candidate batteries. As a result, the metal hydride electrode materials must have proper properties at high environment temperature.

Ti–Ni-based alloy has been widely used because of its promising physical and chemical properties: shape memory alloy and hydrogen storage. The Ti–Ni-based electrode alloys, including Ti2Ni, TiNi [14–17] have all been studied before. For the TiNiH phase all hydrogen was electrochemically dischargeable, while for the Ti2NiH2.5 phase only 40–50% of the hydrogen was reversible in alkaline solution. When the sintered mixture of Ti2Ni and TiNi was sintered, the discharge capacity was higher than the sum of the discharge capacities of Ti2Ni and TiNi. Thus, the function of TiNi phase is “electrocatalytic”, and the Ti2Ni phase function as hydrogen “storehouse”.

Based on the above-mentioned discussions, Ti3Ni2 alloy was directly melted, and its properties at different temperatures were investigated. We expect that the mother-alloy is a composite of two phases, namely Ti2Ni and TiNi which are in very close contact with each other and the larger amount of hydrogen stored in the Ti2Ni phase is dischargeable in alkaline solution.

The purity of original Ti was >99.5% and >99.95% for Ni. Ti3Ni2 alloy was prepared by arc melting under Ar atmosphere and was remelted four times to ensure homogeneity. The alloy ingot was decrepitated to small particles by hydriding and dehydriding cyclings for both XRD analysis and electrochemical tests. Test electrode preparation was reported in detail previously [18]: The alloy powder was mixed with Ni powder in the weight ratio of 1:2, and pressed to form a round-disc electrode of 10 mm diameter (about 100 mg hydrogen storage alloy per pellet). Electrode pellets were tested at various temperatures in an open cell in an electrolyte of 6 mol/lKOH with Hg/HgO/6 mol/l KOH as the reference electrode and Ni(OH)2/NiOOH as the counter electrode. The electrochemical parameters for testing were the following:
1.
For activation behavior and discharge capacity tests, charging at 25 mA/g and discharging at 25 mA/g to the end point.
2.
For high-rate-discharge capacity tests, charging at 25 mA/g and discharging at 125mA/g to the end point.
3.
For self-discharge (24 h) tests, charging at 25 mA/g, after 24 h open circuit, then discharging at 25 mA/g to the end point.
4.
For cycling life measurement, charging at 125 mA/g and discharging at 125 mA/g per cycle, measuring the discharge capacity after every 40–50 cycles at 25 mA/g.
The end point of the discharge was set at −0.6 V(vs. Hg/HgO reference electrode). For XRD analysis, a Philips X'pert MPD diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (0.15405 nm) was used, the scanning rate was 0.02°, the scanning region was 15–150°, and the step time was 0.5 s. The line-polarization resistance was measured by the following method: after full activation of all tested electrodes, charging at 25 mA/g, the line-polarization curves were then tested after 2–3 h of open circuit. For overpotential <30 mV , the ratio of the overpotential and current is the line-polarization resistance (η/i), as described in Ref. [19].

The electrochemical properties of Ti3Ni2 electrode alloy, including discharge capacity, activation cycle number, high-rate dischargeability (HRD) and self-discharge within 24 h, are listed in Table 1, from which it can be seen that the discharge capacity is improved greatly from 145.5 to 384.2 mA h/g (the corresponding hydride is Ti3Ni2H3.7), as the temperature increases from 278 to 353 K. Meanwhile, the activation behavior is improved and the activation cycle number decreases. For example, as the temperature increases from 278 to 353 K, the activation cycle number decreases from 6 to 1.

At a higher temperature, the alloy electrode has a better charge retention. The self-discharge rate decreases as temperature increases. The retention of charge of Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode is 99.4% at 353 K and 62.2% at 278 K, respectively. The effect of temperature on the high-rate-discharge ability is large. HRD improves from 36.0 to 84.4% as temperature increases from 278 to 353 K. This means that the discharge ability of this alloy electrode is very sensitive to temperature. Compared with AB5-type alloy, however, the high-rate dischargeability of Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode is poor at room temperature. For M1(NiMnTi)4.2Co0.8 hydrogen storage alloy, the C300/C60 is 78.5%, while for Ti3Ni2 it is around 30%. Increasing the environment temperature, the activation of the Ti3Ni2 alloy electrodes improves as shown in Table 1. When the environment temperature is higher than 323 K, the maximum discharge capacity is reached at the first charging–discharging cycle.

For Ti–Ni-based binary alloys, the discharge capacity increases and the capacity decays faster as the content of titanium in the alloy increases. The cycling stability of the Ti3Ni2 electrode alloy for different temperatures is shown in Fig. 1 from which it can be seen that the maximum discharge capacity of the Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode increases as the environment temperature increases. But it decays very fast, especially at higher temperatures: after a few cycles, the discharge capacity at 353 K is lower than others; after about 200–250 cycles the discharge capacity at 323 K is lower than that at 278 K. The experimental results show that the attenuation of discharge capacity after 300 cycles for Ti3Ni2 electrode is 32.4% for 278 K, 65.8% for 323 K and 91.5% for 353 K, respectively.

The line-polarization behavior of the Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode is shown in Figs. 2 and 3. It can be seen that the polarization decreases as the temperature increases. But the polarization of the Ti3Ni2 alloy is much larger than that of AB5-type alloy at the same current density. For example, at 353 K, the line polarization resistance of the Ti3Ni2 alloy is 1.2 Ω , and that of M1(NiCoAlMn)5 is 0.2 Ω . This is the reason for the poor kinetics of Ti3Ni2. Increasing the environment temperature from 278 to 353 K decreased the line polarization resistance from 4.7 to 1.2 Ω . The limiting current increases with increasing temperature as shown in Fig. 2. This indicates that an increase in the environment temperature improves the electrochemical process at alloy grain surface and promotes the hydrogen diffusion process.

The discharge curves of the Ti3Ni2 alloy at various temperatures are shown in Fig. 4 and the discharge curve of M1(NiCoAlMn)5 alloy is also plotted in the figure for comparison. It can be seen that at 353 K there are two discharge curve plateaus, one being the fastigiate plateau at the −980 to −790 mV region, and another being the flatter one at the −740 to −690 mV region, from which we believe that the directly melted Ti3Ni2 alloy is a composite of two different phases. At 323 and 278 K, there is only one plateau on the discharge curves.

The ingot of the Ti3Ni2 alloy was difficult to be crushed because of its roughness. The X-ray diffraction pattern of the Ti3Ni2 alloy powder particulated by means of hydriding/dehydriding process is shown in Fig. 5A and that of the Ti3Ni2 alloy after being cycled in alkaline solution is shown in Fig. 5B. From the patterns, a cubic Ti2NiH0.5 phase with the Fe3W3C-type structure and a cubic TiNiH phase are found to co-exist in the hydrided alloy prepared by hydrogen decrepitation. A cubic Ti2NiH phase with an Fe3W3C-type structure and a cubic TiNiH phase are found in the sample after electrochemical reaction. The presence of two hydrides is consistent with the appearance of two discharge plateaus.

The exchange current density (I 0), HRD and hydrogen diffusion coefficient (D
α ) of Ti3Ni2 alloy at different temperatures have also been investigated. At the constant discharge current condition, the diffusion coefficient of hydrogen for our testing condition can be expressed by the following equation [20]:
Dα= r0 2I d
15(Q0−τI d ) .
The exchange current of the alloy electrode can be calculated from the following equation [21]:
I0= RT nF
η i
−1,
where I 0 represents the exchange current density, R the gas constant. n the number of exchange electrons, F the Faraday constant, η the overpotential at current i,η/i the line-polarization resistance, D
α the hydrogen diffusion coefficient in the solid, r 0 the average radius of alloy grains, I d the discharge current, τ the transition time, Q 0 the discharge capacity at a very small current, and T the environment temperature.

Generally speaking, the exchange current I 0 represents the electrocatalytic activity of surface reaction of the alloy grains. For alloys used as electrode materials for Ni–MH battery, the I 0 and D
α are higher, and the HRD is better. In our testing conditions, the variation of I 0,D
α and HRD of the Ti3Ni2 electrode alloy with the temperature is given in Fig. 6, from which it can be seen that the increase in temperature facilitates the diffusion process of hydrogen in the bulk of the alloy and promotes the electrocatalytic activity at the alloy gain surface. As a result, the HRD of alloy electrode is improved as temperature increases because of the increase of both I 0 and D
α namely, the improvement of both the hydrogen diffusion process in the bulk of the alloy and the electrocatalytic activity at the surface of alloy grain.

We inferred that the poor cycling stability of Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode is due to the corrosion of alloy, especially titanium corrosion. In order to overcome and solve this problem and improve the cycling stability, we intend to introduce some elements that have a strong resistance to corrosion from alkaline solution of this alloy, such as Cr, Co and Al.

The results show that the discharge capacity of the Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode reaches 384.4 mAh/g (corresponding to Ti3Ni2H3.7) at 353 K and 145.5 mAh/g (corresponding to Ti3Ni2H1.47) at 278 K. The discharge capacity is higher than that of the commercial AB5 alloy electrode. The discharge curve has two plateaus at 353 K and only one plateau at 278 K. Compared with M1(NiCoMnAl)5 electrode alloy, the high-rate-discharge ability of the Ti3Ni2 alloy electrode is poor. A higher temperature (353 K) accelerates the diffusion process of hydrogen in alloy bulk (i.e. D
α ), increases the surface electrochemical reaction rate at alloy grains surface (i.e. I 0) and improves the charge retention, the high-rate-discharge ability and activation behavior of the alloy, decreases self-discharge rate. However, the cycling life of the alloy and kinetic property of the alloy are still low in comparison with those of M1(NiCoMnAl)5. Further work should be done.
